headline: How Renault’s Long‑Term Ford EV Supply Deal At Renault (ENXTPA:RNO) Has Changed Its Investment Story
summary: In December 2025, Renault Group and Ford announced a long-term European collaboration under which Renault’s Ampere platform and ElectriCity plants in northern France will develop and build two Ford‑branded electric cars, with the first model expected to reach showrooms in early 2028. The partnership not only deepens Renault’s role as an EV technology and manufacturing supplier, but also explores joint light commercial vehicle development, potentially broadening Renault’s revenue...

headline: Ford retreats from EVs, takes $19.5 billion charge as Trump policies grip autos
summary:
STORY: Ford is stopping several of its electric-vehicle models and will take a $19.5 billion writedown.

That was the word from the U.S. auto major on Monday (December 15).

It's the strongest sign yet of the auto industry's pullback from battery-powered models.

Ford said it will replace the full electric F-150 Lightning with a new extended-range electric model that uses a gas-powered engine to recharge the battery.

The company also cancelled a next-generation electric truck, code-named the T3, as well as planned electric commercial vans.

Ford CEO Jim Farley said the market changed over the last couple of months and drove the carmaker's decision.

Adding that it will pivot hard into gas and hybrid models, and eventually hire thousands of workers.

The company expects its global mix of hybrids, extended-range EVs and pure EVs to reach 50% by 2030 - up from 17% today.

The outlook for electrics dimmed this year as U.S. President Donald Trump’s policies pulled federal support for EVs.

Trump also eased tailpipe-emissions rules, which could encourage carmakers to sell more gas-powered cars.

U.S. sales of electric vehicles fell about 40% in November - that followed the end of a $7,500 consumer tax credit in September.

Ford isn't alone in changing its approach to EVs.

General Motors took a $1.6 billion charge in October as it adjusted its EV factory plans.

While Stellantis also backtracked on some of its EV plans and leaned into hybrids.

Ford also said Monday it will spread out the multi-billion dollar writedown over a few quarters.

And it raised its guidance for this year's adjusted earnings before interest and taxes, to about $7 billion.

That was up from a previous range of $6 billion to $6.5 billion.

content.title: Ford retreats from EVs, takes $19.5 billion charge as Trump policies grip autos
content.summary:

Ford CEO Jim Farley said the market changed over the last couple of months and drove the carmaker's decision.

Adding that it will pivot hard into gas and hybrid models, and eventually hire thousands of workers.

The company expects its global mix of hybrids, extended-range EVs and pure EVs to reach 50% by 2030 - up from 17% today.

The outlook for electrics dimmed this year as U.S. President Donald Trump’s policies pulled federal support for EVs.

Trump also eased tailpipe-emissions rules, which could encourage carmakers to sell more gas-powered cars.

U.S. sales of electric vehicles fell about 40% in November - that followed the end of a $7,500 consumer tax credit in September.

headline: Heard on the Street Recap: Late Jobs Report Still Leaves a Mark
summary: In a report delayed by the government shutdown, the Labor Department said Tuesday that the unemployment rate rose to 4.6% in November--it’s highest level in more than four years.  The Dow and S&P 500 closed the day in the red, despite gains by most of the megacap tech stocks.  The Dow fell 302 points, or 0.6%.

The Dow and S&P 500 closed the day in the red, despite gains by most of the megacap tech stocks.  The Dow fell 302 points, or 0.6%.

headline: The Electric Car Transition Unravels Slowly, Then All at Once
summary: The European Commission backed away from what had been the world’s most aggressive timeline for phasing out internal-combustion engines, granting manufacturers and consumers more time to move off gasoline.  A day earlier, Ford Motor Co. announced $19.5 billion in charges tied to the retreat from an electric strategy it vowed to go all in on eight years ago.

content.title: The Electric Car Transition Unravels Slowly, Then All at Once
content.summary: The European Commission backed away from what had been the world’s most aggressive timeline for phasing out internal-combustion engines, granting manufacturers and consumers more time to move off gasoline.  A day earlier, Ford Motor Co. announced $19.5 billion in charges tied to the retreat from an electric strategy it vowed to go all in on eight years ago.

headline: US adds 64K jobs in November, Ford navigates $19.5B hit from EV pivot
summary: Morning Brief host Julie Hyman breaks down the biggest market stories developing on December 16, 2025. RSM chief economist Joe Brusuelas, Columbia Threadneedle global rates strategist Ed Al-Hussainy, and Academy Securities head of macro strategy Peter Tchir help Julie react to the delayed November jobs report, which saw the US labor market grow by 64,000 non-farm payroll jobs last month after shrinking by 105,000 in October amid the government shutdown. An expert team of Yahoo Finance senior reporters Jennifer Schonberger, Brooke DiPalma, and Pras Subramanian monitor how the Federal Reserve may be interpreting this latest economic data, the latest retail sales data print, and Ford's (F) $19.5 billion in charges it will take on as it pivots away from electric vehicles (EVs). To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

content.title: US adds 64K jobs in November, Ford navigates $19.5B hit from EV pivot
content.description:
Morning Brief host Julie Hyman breaks down the biggest market stories developing on December 16, 2025.

RSM chief economist Joe Brusuelas, Columbia Threadneedle global rates strategist Ed Al-Hussainy, and Academy Securities head of macro strategy Peter Tchir help Julie react to the delayed November jobs report, which saw the US labor market grow by 64,000 non-farm payroll jobs last month after shrinking by 105,000 in October amid the government shutdown.

An expert team of Yahoo Finance senior reporters Jennifer Schonberger, Brooke DiPalma, and Pras Subramanian monitor how the Federal Reserve may be interpreting this latest economic data, the latest retail sales data print, and Ford's (F) $19.5 billion in charges it will take on as it pivots away from electric vehicles (EVs).

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.
content.summary: Morning Brief host Julie Hyman breaks down the biggest market stories developing on December 16, 2025. RSM chief economist Joe Brusuelas, Columbia Threadneedle global rates strategist Ed Al-Hussainy, and Academy Securities head of macro strategy Peter Tchir help Julie react to the delayed November jobs report, which saw the US labor market grow by 64,000 non-farm payroll jobs last month after shrinking by 105,000 in October amid the government shutdown. An expert team of Yahoo Finance senior reporters Jennifer Schonberger, Brooke DiPalma, and Pras Subramanian monitor how the Federal Reserve may be interpreting this latest economic data, the latest retail sales data print, and Ford's (F) $19.5 billion in charges it will take on as it pivots away from electric vehicles (EVs). To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Ford to take $19.5 billion hit in move away from EVs: What to know
summary: Ford (F) expects to take on $19,5 billion in charges over its pivot to hybrid and extended range EVs (EREV) from full electric vehicles. This new strategy includes the cancellation of the F-150 Lightning. Yahoo Finance senior autos reporter Pras Subramanian breaks it all down. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Ford scraps EV plans, shifts to hybrids, EREVs and low-cost models
summary: The automaker will focus its North American EV development on a new family of smaller, highly efficient and less expensive models.

thumbnail.caption: Doug Field, Ford's chief EV, digital and design officer, speaks at a presentation in August 2025 announcing the automaker's new Universal EV Platform. The The platform will underpin a family of smaller, highly efficient and low-cost EVs.
